Concept Drift

Feb 25, 2021 • Stefano Meschiari

It’s very rare for both the underlying generative processes that produce the raw data, and the systems we use to measure, transform, and store that raw data, to be static and unchanging. More commonly, they evolve: distributions shift, relationships and constraints between the different dimensions of the data drift and break, and assumptions about the semantics of certain attributes cease to be valid. Those shifts can happen on different timescales, and sometimes in abrupt ways.

This can have a profound effect on machine learning models. In the best case scenario, predictive performance might be degraded; a monitoring component might be able to detect this regression, attribute it to a specific root cause, and trigger a retrain using a different dataset. In the worst case, it will serve catastrophically non-sensical results.

What is concept drift?

Concept drift is a shift in the relationship between covariates ($X$) and the target variable ($y$). There is concept drift when the joint distribution $p(X, y)$ is changing (therefore, it also encompasses data drift – changing $p(X)$ – and label shift – changing $p(y)$).

The “concept” in the name is the latent context that defined that relationship between $X$ and $y$. Concept drift might cover both a slow trend, where $p(X, y)$ might evolve over a long timescale, and situations where the data changed abruptly due to discontinuous changes in the data generation mechanism.

In a supervised domain (where the label $y$ is known), concept drift typically manifests itself in reduced predictive performance. In an unsupervised domain (where the labels are not known, or only a small subset is known, or they are only captured after substantial latency), even recognizing this problem is more challenging. In the unsupervised domain, the only observables are the covariates; since $y$ is latent, any concurrent shift in the relationship of the covariates with the notion of anomaly will need to be reduced to changes in $p(X)$ set, or induced via external knowledge.
